storyline_title: 1789 France suffered a deep financial cr
storyline: Scene:  1#   1789 France suffered a deep financial crisis. King Louis XVI of France called the Estates-General. They discuss possible solutions. It came to disputes on the voting system. The National Assembly was formed. Soon later the French Revolution took place. The conventions opend on May 5th 1789 with great festivities.

storyline_title: The same day, Heinrich Weiss was born in
storyline: Scene:  2#   The same day, Heinrich Weiss was born in Fehraltorf, Canton Zürich, Switzerland, into a decent teacher's family.

storyline_title: 1795 one year earlier the Treaty of Base
storyline: Scene:  3#   1795 one year earlier the Treaty of Basel signed peace between France and Prussia. 1796France had occupied the Prussian Rhine land and the Revolt in the Vendée had just ended. The Battle of Lodi had significantly contributed to the myth of Napoleon who would set up the Cisalpine Republic in the same year seizing the Valtellina from Graubünden (the "Grey Leagues") and causing tensions in the Italian speaking Switzerland after an unsuccessful trial to invade Lugano in today's Canton Ticino.

storyline_title: 1790 Katharina Kaufmann was born in Horw
storyline: Scene:  4#   1790 Katharina Kaufmann was born in Horw, on May 23.

storyline_title: 1797 Meta (actually Anna Margaretha Barb
storyline: Scene:  5#   1797 Meta (actually Anna Margaretha Barbara) Schweizer was born in Hirzel, in the Canton Zürich on the border with the Canton Zug.

storyline_title: 1798, March 5th, the French finally inva
storyline: Scene:  6#   1798, March 5th, the French finally invaded Switzerland helped by Swiss nationals (de La Harpe) who hoped to end with the feudal system of the Old Swiss Confederation, then converted into the Helvetic Republic subject to France. The French had taken the independence of the Swiss Cantons away and formed a centralized state, whose "progressive" ideas included such controversial measurements like the limitation of the freedom of worship.

storyline_title: The forest cantons led by Alois von Redi
storyline: Scene:  7#   The forest cantons led by Alois von Reding made an intent of resistence. Therefore, the French occupied Zürich in order to defeat the rising upheavals in Switzerland. The enforced treaty with France obliged the Swiss to break their neutrality, which converted them into a battle zone between France, Austria and the armies of Imperial Russia.

storyline_title: 1800 Katharina Kaufmann's mother died an
storyline: Scene:  8#   1800 Katharina Kaufmann's mother died and she went to live with her aunt in Kriens.

storyline_title: The next year in Lodrino, Canton Ticino,
storyline: Scene:  9#   The next year in Lodrino, Canton Ticino, on October 10th, 1801, Constantin Siegwart was born into a glassworker's family, originally immigrated from Germany.

storyline_title: The locals allied mostly with Austria or
storyline: Scene:  10#   The locals allied mostly with Austria or Russia against France. A series of violent encounters started and culminated in the Stecklikrieg ("wooden club war") during which Zürich was bombarded 1802, as Meta Schweizer remembered.

storyline_title: On 19 February 1803 the Act of Mediation
storyline: Scene:  11#   On 19 February 1803 the Act of Mediation was signed by Napoleon, ending the Helvetic Republic and restoring the cantons and the Swiss Confederation. Formally, this was the begin of the Mediation period in Swiss history.

storyline_title: While Heinrich Weiss, Katharina Kaufmann
storyline: Scene:  12#   While Heinrich Weiss, Katharina Kaufmann and Meta Schweizer grew up, learned in school and in their offices, Heinrich Weiss would become a teacher, Katharina Kaufmann served in several restaurants and Meta Schweizer was educated as a house wife, learned under house teachers and took great interest in international affairs of her days.

storyline_title: 1804, from Mach 24 to April 3, the Bocke
storyline: Scene:  13#   1804, from Mach 24 to April 3, the Bocke inn war took place on the mount Bocken near Horgen, a town close to Hirzel were Meta Schweizer lived. The rural population rioted against the Confederate troops, led by Zürich in order to abolish the tithes.

storyline_title: This event marked Meta Schweizer, becaus
storyline: Scene:  14#   This event marked Meta Schweizer, because it taught her how neighbours could become enemies.

storyline_title: September 2, 1806 a landslide burried th
storyline: Scene:  15#   September 2, 1806 a landslide burried the towns Goldau and Röthen completly, as well as part of Buosingen and Lauerz. 457 persons died. It was so far the second larges natural catastroph in Switzerland after the Basel earthquake 1356.

storyline_title: This event entered into the memories of
storyline: Scene:  16#   This event entered into the memories of Katharina Morel, who lived close, and Meta Schweizer, who visited the region often during her life.

storyline_title: 1806 the annuary of Zurich-Schwyz friend
storyline: Scene:  17#   1806 the annuary of Zurich-Schwyz friendship was celebrated, as Meta Schweizer recorded.

storyline_title: The same year, Katharina Kaufmann marrie
storyline: Scene:  18#   The same year, Katharina Kaufmann married Heinrich Peyer converting her into Katharina Peyer, Heinrich Weiss went to the high school in Aarau and Prussia declared war to France. Napoleon imposed the Continental system.

storyline_title: The following year, Bernhard Hirzel was
storyline: Scene:  19#   The following year, Bernhard Hirzel was born 12 August 1807 into well established, aristocratic family of Zürich.

storyline_title: The same year Napoleon signed peace with
storyline: Scene:  20#   The same year Napoleon signed peace with Prussia and Russia in Tilsit.

storyline_title: 1808 Constantin Siegwart lost both of hi
storyline: Scene:  21#   1808 Constantin Siegwart lost both of his parents and became the foster son of Joseph Maria Regli, a Catholic priest who would educate him as his own son, providing him with the best education, religious teaching an foremost fatherly love.

storyline_title: During these years Meta Schweizer made m
storyline: Scene:  22#   During these years Meta Schweizer made many travels to the forest cantons, especially to the Schwyz and the Rigi.

storyline_title: In November 1809, Heinrich Peyer listed
storyline: Scene:  23#   In November 1809, Heinrich Peyer listed voluntarily the mercenary service for France in Marseille, and a few month later Katharina followed her husband, end of July 1810.

storyline_title: In September of the same year Jakob Heus
storyline: Scene:  24#   In September of the same year Jakob Heusser, who should later become the husband of Meta Schweizer, moved to Hirzel as the general practitionar of the town.

storyline_title: End of 1811, Maria Elise Tobler, the fut
storyline: Scene:  25#   End of 1811, Maria Elise Tobler, the future wife of Bernhard Hirzel was born. On the Hirzel mountain, Caspar (?) Gessner (1780-1812), a distant but dear relative of Meta Schweizer, would visite her for the last time, while Katharina and Heinrich Peyer see the French Majesties from very close during a parade in Paris.

storyline_title: On the 13 January 1812, Katharina Peyer
storyline: Scene:  26#   On the 13 January 1812, Katharina Peyer and her husband received the order to march to Lüttich without clear destiny.

storyline_title: In April they arrive at Stettin where th
storyline: Scene:  27#   In April they arrive at Stettin where the four Swiss regiments join. Still waiting for Napoleon they run out of food. Katharina Peyer wrote a significant letter to her sister Anna-Marie, telling her that now she had learnt what war meant.

storyline_title: At the same time Meta Schweizer burried
storyline: Scene:  28#   At the same time Meta Schweizer burried her relative and friend Caspar Gessner. Travells to the Aegeri mountain and the Rigi followed, where she heard of spiritual visions some of her acquantaince had experienced.

storyline_title: In June, Meta Schweizer knew Jakob Heuss
storyline: Scene:  29#   In June, Meta Schweizer knew Jakob Heusser better during extended walks.

storyline_title: In the meanwhile, finally, Napoleon had
storyline: Scene:  30#   In the meanwhile, finally, Napoleon had joined the Swiss regiments and they arrive at the Niemen. He informed them about their mission, to invade Russia.

storyline_title: On the 18 October 1812 Katharina Peyer p
storyline: Scene:  31#   On the 18 October 1812 Katharina Peyer presented the battle of Polotz at close distance and helped to care for the wounded. In Switzerland, the news about the war provided only insignificant details about the culture of the country and the surprisingly warm weather.

storyline_title: One month later on the 28th of November
storyline: Scene:  32#   One month later on the 28th of November the Swiss mercenaries prepared for the battle on the street between Barisow and Zumbin. Franz Josef Blattman motivated Thomas Legler to sing the "Beresinalied", which would end mythology about Swiss heroism, and is shot soon after. The day after the Peyers leave Königsberg to return to Polotz.

storyline_title: Finally, the Swiss at home hear about th
storyline: Scene:  33#   Finally, the Swiss at home hear about the negative balance of Napoleon's Russian campaign and the end of the Empire.

storyline_title: Threatened by the Russian troops the Pey
storyline: Scene:  34#   Threatened by the Russian troops the Peyers fled and arrived on Januar 31, 1813 in Berlin. Marburg, Düsseldorf and Hanover were occupied by the Allies.

storyline_title: The Peyers decide to flee to Switzerland
storyline: Scene:  35#   The Peyers decide to flee to Switzerland given the unstable situation in Germany. In Magdeburg they loose their last goods. In March, the Peyers arrive at Lautenburg close to Switzerland while the Russian had advanced until Berlin.

storyline_title: The 6 of April 1813 the French and the P
storyline: Scene:  36#   The 6 of April 1813 the French and the Prussians meet at the Elbe. Three days later was the confirmation day of Meta Schweizer in Hirzel. In the following month she would travell to St. Gallen where she started her friendship with Schlatters.

storyline_title: In May of the same year, the Peyers left
storyline: Scene:  37#   In May of the same year, the Peyers left Lauterburg and arrived at Basel. Back home in Luzern, Katharina Peyer visited her friends.

storyline_title: In July an alliance between England and
storyline: Scene:  38#   In July an alliance between England and Sweden was made, and the Peace Congress in Prag came closer. All the four armies of the four monarchies were advancing on German grounds and terrible war armament took place at all sides.

storyline_title: August 26, Meta Schweizer returned from
storyline: Scene:  39#   August 26, Meta Schweizer returned from one of her trips to the Rigi.

storyline_title: In September, Katharina Peyer reported t
storyline: Scene:  40#   In September, Katharina Peyer reported there was war from the Adratic Sea to the Baltic Sea and Moscow in flames.

storyline_title: 15 November 1813 extraordinary Diet of t
storyline: Scene:  41#   15 November 1813 extraordinary Diet of the Swiss Confederation in Zürich was held and armed neutrality was declared unilaterally, soon after the Ticino was cleaned up of Italian troops and the French withdraw from the German Rhine region.

storyline_title: Meta Schweizer remembered the 18th of Oc
storyline: Scene:  42#   Meta Schweizer remembered the 18th of October as the day of the salvation battle in Leibzig.

storyline_title: Heinrich Peyer had tried to retake his j
storyline: Scene:  43#   Heinrich Peyer had tried to retake his job as saddler again in Willisau, but due to the bad payment policies, he was not very succesful. Therefore, he decided to enter military service again and left after a short job in Graubünden to Maastrich in French service, on the 7th of December 1813 together with his wife Katharina.

storyline_title: On the 17th Colon was occupied an the al
storyline: Scene:  44#   On the 17th Colon was occupied an the allies advanced to Holland. The Peyers arrived nine days later. Katharina Peyer would run a kind of Pension for high military officers in Maastrich.

storyline_title: The same year, Bernhard Hirzel's grandfa
storyline: Scene:  45#   The same year, Bernhard Hirzel's grandfather died.

storyline_title: In 1814 most of the Swiss cantons were r
storyline: Scene:  46#   In 1814 most of the Swiss cantons were ruled by the former aristocratic powers. This threatened the territorial integrity of the new cantons formed under the Act of Mediation. The Russian Zar Alexander I. visited Zürich and influenced by de La Harpe, spoke in favor of the new cantons.

storyline_title: The year 1815 was memorized by Meta Schw
storyline: Scene:  47#   The year 1815 was memorized by Meta Schweizer as the "victory by Waterloo". This marked the end of the Mediation and the beginning of the Restauration period from which she hoped more religious liberty. For Meta Schweizer it was also the beginning of a lifelong aristocratic friendship with the Family Ab Yberg from the canton Schwyz.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart rememberd the year f
storyline: Scene:  48#   Constantin Siegwart rememberd the year for the Federal Treaty.

storyline_title: In the meantime, Katharina Peyer, hired
storyline: Scene:  49#   In the meantime, Katharina Peyer, hired a ship for the Swiss troops, in order to solve their logistic problems in their transfer to Gorum, but foremost, in her own interest, getting free freight for her household.

storyline_title: In 1817, in middst of the Swiss Restaura
storyline: Scene:  50#   In 1817, in middst of the Swiss Restauration and two years after the Congress of Vienna, while Heinrich Weiss was a committed teacher, Katharina Peyer had shown succesfully arriving at Gorum, Meta Schweizer networked her oecomenic friendship networks, Constantin Siegwart studied with his home teacher and Bernhard Hirzel at the primary school, a new dream of liberty was born. In Berlin on May 10 was Emma Siegmund born and in Stuttgart on the 31st her future husband Georg Herwegh.

storyline_title: 7 March 1818 was marked as an important
storyline: Scene:  51#   7 March 1818 was marked as an important day in Meta Schweizer-Heusser memoires. Her husband Jakob Heusser, so far distant from religious matters, had committed to the Christian faith. Soon after in June they engaged.

storyline_title: 1818 Constantin Siegwart assisted the sc
storyline: Scene:  52#   1818 Constantin Siegwart assisted the schools in Altorf, Luzern and Solothurn, where he started friendship with radical-liberals as Ludwig Keller, Eduard Kathry, Joseph Kölscher. They studied with Professor Weissenbach and founded the Rütliverein. He also entered the Freundschaftsbund with Melchior Tschümperlin.

storyline_title: 1819 Constantin Siegwart studied philoso
storyline: Scene:  53#   1819 Constantin Siegwart studied philosophy, political sciences and jurisprudence in Würzburg and Heidelberg.

storyline_title: Bernhard Hirzel started his studies at t
storyline: Scene:  54#   Bernhard Hirzel started his studies at the grammar school at the Schola Carolina at the Grossmünster in Zürich

storyline_title: Meta Schweizer made several voyages amon
storyline: Scene:  55#   Meta Schweizer made several voyages among others to the Rigi and her life was marked by the birth and death of relatives and other beloved people.

storyline_title: 1820 Heinrich Weiss became teacher in Fe
storyline: Scene:  56#   1820 Heinrich Weiss became teacher in Fehraltorf. At the same time, Constantin Siegwart returned to his former Catholic faith.

storyline_title: The following year in January 1821, Hein
storyline: Scene:  57#   The following year in January 1821, Heinrich Peyer dismissed from military service and the Peyers return in a 21-days-travel to Switzerland in horse carrier through Aachen, Lüttich, Köln, Koblenz, Speyer, Salzbach, Freiburg, Basel, Zofingen, to Willisau.

storyline_title: Three month later, on the 9th of April 1
storyline: Scene:  58#   Three month later, on the 9th of April 1821, Meta Schweizer finally, after a three-years fiancee could marrie to Jakob Heusser. She continous to travel to the Rigi.

storyline_title: On 15 February 1822 Katharina and Heinri
storyline: Scene:  59#   On 15 February 1822 Katharina and Heinrich Peyer move to Sursee and run the Inn "Zum Rössli".

storyline_title: On 13 August 1822 Theodor Diethelm Heuss
storyline: Scene:  60#   On 13 August 1822 Theodor Diethelm Heusser, Meta Heusser-Schweizer's first son was born.

storyline_title: 1823 Meta Heusser-Schweizer visited Luze
storyline: Scene:  61#   1823 Meta Heusser-Schweizer visited Luzern.

storyline_title: In the same year, Heinrich Peyer's siste
storyline: Scene:  62#   In the same year, Heinrich Peyer's sister died and left her young daughter to the care of Katharina Peyer.

storyline_title: In December, Hirzel graduated from the 3
storyline: Scene:  63#   In December, Hirzel graduated from the 3rd class of the grammar school and enters the Collegium humanitatis at the Fraumünster (upper school)

storyline_title: 28 January 1825, Meta Schweizer-Heusser'
storyline: Scene:  64#   28 January 1825, Meta Schweizer-Heusser's first daugher Anna Elisabetha Dorothea was born.

storyline_title: Katharina and Heinrich leave the "Rössli
storyline: Scene:  65#   Katharina and Heinrich leave the "Rössli" and start the "Bad Rothen" in Littau during two years.

storyline_title: 14 December 1825 Bernhard Hirzel graduat
storyline: Scene:  66#   14 December 1825 Bernhard Hirzel graduated from upper school and enters the Collegium Carolinum at the Grossmünster, focus on Classis philologica (ancient languages, history), Classis philosphica.

storyline_title: In the year to follow, Meta Heusser-Schw
storyline: Scene:  67#   In the year to follow, Meta Heusser-Schweizer would often stay in Baden.

storyline_title: March 28th of the following year Jakob C
storyline: Scene:  68#   March 28th of the following year Jakob Christian Heusser, Meta Heusser-Schweizer’s second son. She would soon fear for his life, but he would recover happily.

storyline_title: Bernhard Hirzel engaged with Maria Elisa
storyline: Scene:  69#   Bernhard Hirzel engaged with Maria Elisa (Elise) Tobler and soon after graduated from Classis philologica and philosophica and starts Classis theologica (theological studies).

storyline_title: 1826 Constantin Siegwart wrote his "Tell
storyline: Scene:  70#   1826 Constantin Siegwart wrote his "Tell der Urner" and achieved citizenship in Uri.

storyline_title: Heinrich Weiss became member of the trib
storyline: Scene:  71#   Heinrich Weiss became member of the tribunal of the district Kyburg and married Anna Barbara Tobler who would die soon after.

storyline_title: 12 June 1827 Meta Heusser-Schweizer's ga
storyline: Scene:  72#   12 June 1827 Meta Heusser-Schweizer's gave birth to her second daugher Johanna Louise.

storyline_title: In the same year Constantin Siegwart bec
storyline: Scene:  73#   In the same year Constantin Siegwart became public prosecutor (Landesfürsprech) in Uri.

storyline_title: Also Heinrich Weiss married for the seco
storyline: Scene:  74#   Also Heinrich Weiss married for the second time to Margaretha Zwicky.

storyline_title: Katharina Peyer leased the Inn "Engel" i
storyline: Scene:  75#   Katharina Peyer leased the Inn "Engel" in Luzern.

storyline_title: 1828 Meta Heusser-Schweizer met with Ger
storyline: Scene:  76#   1828 Meta Heusser-Schweizer met with Gerold Meyer, later an important biographer and historiographer and Wichelhausens.

storyline_title: The same year, Bernhard Hirzel graduated
storyline: Scene:  77#   The same year, Bernhard Hirzel graduated from theology after a very short time of study and with excellent records.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart married Josefine Mül
storyline: Scene:  78#   Constantin Siegwart married Josefine Müller, daughter of Karl Martin Müller and sister of Vinzenz and Franz and would call himself from then on Constantin Siegwart-Müller.

storyline_title: 26 May 1829 Meta Heusser-Schweizer gave
storyline: Scene:  79#   26 May 1829 Meta Heusser-Schweizer gave life to her third son Heinrich Willhelm. He would die only 16 days later.

storyline_title: 1830 was the beginning of a new, liberal
storyline: Scene:  80#   1830 was the beginning of a new, liberal era iniciated with the July Revolution in Paris. Already in 1819 the Association Zofingia (Zofingerverein) was founded by the liberals in Zürich, the patriotic Sempacher Association (Sempacherverein), in 1821, the Schweizerische Schützenverein, a Swiss schooting association, in 1824 as well as several Gymnastic and choral societies in which liberal thinking men were organized. Another important role played the press in this change.

storyline_title: 1830-1833 The cantonal Constitutions wer
storyline: Scene:  81#   1830-1833 The cantonal Constitutions were changed with a Liberal orientation, beginning in new Cantons Vaud and Ticino, who were former subject to Bern and Zürich during the Ancien Régim.

storyline_title: Simultaneously, the press and the immigr
storyline: Scene:  82#   Simultaneously, the press and the immigration control (Fremdenpolizei) were restricted in several cantons. Also in the forest cantons liberal movements achieved a constitutional change.

storyline_title: During this turbulent times, Heinrich We
storyline: Scene:  83#   During this turbulent times, Heinrich Weiss became member of the Grand Council on the 9 December 1830.

storyline_title: One of his most important contributions
storyline: Scene:  84#   One of his most important contributions would be the abolition of tithes claims. His presenting of the Day of Uster (Ustertag) and bringing forward Snells proposal of a liberal Constitution in the following year 1831.

storyline_title: On January 1st of 1831 Bernhard Hirzel p
storyline: Scene:  85#   On January 1st of 1831 Bernhard Hirzel passed his final exam at the Carolinum. In February he recieved an award for his translation of Book of 4 Maccabees and in March he passed an church exam in dogmatic, exegesis and pastoral science by the Church Council which would enable him to be a pastor of the Reformed Church of Zürich. In the same month he preached a sermon as part of the selection process as future pastor and was finally ordinated as VDM (Verbi divini minister); the statues of an official minister of the Protestant Church on March 18th.

storyline_title: Two days later Heinrich Weiss became Mem
storyline: Scene:  86#   Two days later Heinrich Weiss became Member of the State Council (Regierungsrates) as a radical-liberal. Usteri and Wyss became first and second Office Mayors and Ludwig Keller magistrate.

storyline_title: On April the 25th the summer semester st
storyline: Scene:  87#   On April the 25th the summer semester started in Berlin and Hirzel went there to study, among other things, theology with Schleiermacher (1768-1834) and Sanskrit with Franz Bopp (1791-1867). In September he moved to Paris to study with the Sanskritist Antoine Léonard de Chézy (1773-1832). At the end of the same year the Educational councillor Johann Caspar Orelli sugested Hirzel in a letter the possibility for a position as lecture in Hebrew and Biblical Greek was at the Theological Institut in Zürich.

storyline_title: Pfäffikon had become district capital in
storyline: Scene:  88#   Pfäffikon had become district capital instead of Kyburg and in the forest Cantons debates on constitutional reforms went on.

storyline_title: In Luzern, the conservative and later fr
storyline: Scene:  89#   In Luzern, the conservative and later friend of Constantin Siegwart, Joseph Leu had become Grand Councillor.

storyline_title: 28 May 1832 he national democratic Hamba
storyline: Scene:  90#   28 May 1832 he national democratic Hambach Festival advanced the beginning of a new liberal era, the so called Vormärz, in Germany. Emma Siegmund observed the news as a young lady from her parents villa in Berlin.

storyline_title: 31 August 1832 Antoine Léonard de Chézy,
storyline: Scene:  91#   31 August 1832 Antoine Léonard de Chézy, Berhand Hirzel’s Sanskrit professor died. Hirzel was deeply affected as he confessed his friend Bluntschli.

storyline_title: In the following month he published a pr
storyline: Scene:  92#   In the following month he published a preprint of his translation of the 3rd Act of the Sakuntala in the "Morgenblatt für gebildete Stände".

storyline_title: October 1832 were agitated days for Bern
storyline: Scene:  93#   October 1832 were agitated days for Bernhard Hirzel.

storyline_title: On the 20th the Educational council publ
storyline: Scene:  94#   On the 20th the Educational council publishes the vacancies for the new University that should be established in Zürich. After Basel, founded in 1460, the second in Switzerland. It should become a new tool for the liberal development in Zürich. But no chair of Orientalistic was offered, which highly deceived Bernhard Hirzel, who understood, influenced by Hegelian ideas, that Sanskrit was a key to a liberal religious education.

storyline_title: On the 28th a new educational law was es
storyline: Scene:  95#   On the 28th a new educational law was established.

storyline_title: On November 16th, in a letter, Hottinger
storyline: Scene:  96#   On November 16th, in a letter, Hottinger expressed his regret for the lack of a chair in Orientalistic at the university to Hirzel. He added even a reference for Hirzel in the attachement.

storyline_title: In a letter to Bluntschli, Bernhard Hirz
storyline: Scene:  97#   In a letter to Bluntschli, Bernhard Hirzel revealed on the 4th of December that he took the possibility of a chair never very serious.

storyline_title: In the same year, Heinrich Weiss became
storyline: Scene:  98#   In the same year, Heinrich Weiss became president of the Police Council, something like a Superintendent and would be remember by the cantonal police as the as the "leader" of the county up to current days.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart-Müller sent a short
storyline: Scene:  99#   Constantin Siegwart-Müller sent a short publication demonstrating his radical-liberal ideals to Casimir Pfyffer in order to apply for citizenship in Luzern. Which he would achieve soon after in Oberkich, Luzern.

storyline_title: 30 January 1833 the bulwark of the city
storyline: Scene:  100#   30 January 1833 the bulwark of the city of Zürich was downsized.

storyline_title: In February Bernhard Hirzel presented hi
storyline: Scene:  101#   In February Bernhard Hirzel presented his dissertation on "ars metrica des Calidasa", presented at the University Göttingen for which he would receive his doctoral degree from the University of Göttingen.

storyline_title: In March, The Educational council appoin
storyline: Scene:  102#   In March, The Educational council appointed Hirzel as outside lecturer (Privatdozent) for the University Zürich and on April 29, 1833 the University started finally its activity.

storyline_title: Two month later, in June, a great fire b
storyline: Scene:  103#   Two month later, in June, a great fire burned the centre of Luzern down. Katharina Peyer was one of the first in perceiving it and alerting the firemen. She actively helped in saving people and goods during this great brand. The salvation of the city was celebrate in a church mass on 23 June 1833.

storyline_title: In that year, Meta Heusser-Schweizer vis
storyline: Scene:  104#   In that year, Meta Heusser-Schweizer visited frequently friends in Wollishofen. In Wollishofen a second election for pastor hold place on the 17th of November.

storyline_title: 29 November 1833 applied Bernhard Hirzel
storyline: Scene:  105#   29 November 1833 applied Bernhard Hirzel for membership of the Synod of Zurich, with delay after his voyage to Göttingen.

storyline_title: In 1833 he also married to Maria Elise T
storyline: Scene:  106#   In 1833 he also married to Maria Elise Tobler.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart-Müller, in the same
storyline: Scene:  107#   Constantin Siegwart-Müller, in the same year, moved to Luzern, where recently a liberal constitutional proposal was rejected, and started to work as attorney, editor and publisher of the "Volkszeitung" and took active interest in the political and economic development of his canton.

storyline_title: Heinrich Weiss became founded the Saving
storyline: Scene:  108#   Heinrich Weiss became founded the Savings Bank (Sparkasse) of the District Pfäffikon.

storyline_title: The Gotthard pass became passable, throu
storyline: Scene:  109#   The Gotthard pass became passable, through the efforts of the Cantonal government (1830-1840) and steamship cruised on the Lake Lucerne for the first time.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegward-Müller received the
storyline: Scene:  110#   Constantin Siegward-Müller received the citizenship of Einsiedeln {check date}.

storyline_title: 15 March 1834 was the date of death of S
storyline: Scene:  111#   15 March 1834 was the date of death of Schleiermacher’s, Bernhard Hirzel’s teacher in theology, diligently annotated by Meta Heusser-Schweizer in her diary. She passed the summer month July in Schwyz with her friend Josef Anton Alois II. Franz ab Yberg (1783-1864), short Alois, and in by the Ab Ybergs in Seewen. Later on in October she would assist the reunions of her Anabaptist friends and the teachings of Zaremba, one of the missionaris of the Basler Mission who received allowance by Zar Alexander I. to preach in Russia.

storyline_title: 7 October 1834 Elisabeth Tobler gave bir
storyline: Scene:  112#   7 October 1834 Elisabeth Tobler gave birth to Paul Arnold Hirzel; her first and unique son with Bernhard Hirzel.

storyline_title: 1834 was an active year for Heinrich Wei
storyline: Scene:  113#   1834 was an active year for Heinrich Weiss. He became an Official salt merchant (Salzfaktor) and District Judge. In this latter function he tried to improvement of the legal system in the interest of the people.

storyline_title: He was appointed Coronel of the Swiss Co
storyline: Scene:  114#   He was appointed Coronel of the Swiss Confederate troops. Further, he affiliated as a member of the radical-liberal Free-thinking Party and he actively worked also for the takeover of the road traffic system by the Cantonal government.

storyline_title: In 1835 the hotel Schwanden was built in
storyline: Scene:  115#   In 1835 the hotel Schwanden was built in Luzern, next to the Schweizerhof, and until 1855 the only hotel with view on the lake besides the former.

storyline_title: Heinrich Weiss was elected Grand Council
storyline: Scene:  116#   Heinrich Weiss was elected Grand Councillor and founded the secondary school of in Fehraltorf.

storyline_title: 1835 Siewart-Müller became Second State
storyline: Scene:  117#   1835 Siewart-Müller became Second State Secretatry (Staatsschreiber) and was appointed State Secretary.

storyline_title: On 2 January 1836 Meta Heusser-Schweizer
storyline: Scene:  118#   On 2 January 1836 Meta Heusser-Schweizer’s mother died peacefully.

storyline_title: 10 June of the same year, the Catholic C
storyline: Scene:  119#   10 June of the same year, the Catholic Collegium of Grand Councillors (Großrathscollegium) summons an administration for the monastery in Pfäffers, St. Gallen in which Constantin Siegwart-Müller was involved. Also Meta Heusser-Schweizer was concerned since she stood often during her life in the monastery and its sanatory.

storyline_title: Three days later, on the 13th, Heinrich
storyline: Scene:  120#   Three days later, on the 13th, Heinrich Weiss became member and Quaestor of the Swiss welfare organisation, the Schweizerische Gemeinnützige Gesellschaft.

storyline_title: 17 October 1836 Meta Heusser-Schweizer g
storyline: Scene:  121#   17 October 1836 Meta Heusser-Schweizer gave life to her fourth daughter Meta Louise (1836-1904)

storyline_title: In the meantime, the liberal party in Zü
storyline: Scene:  122#   In the meantime, the liberal party in Zürich planned to reform the church by appointing a revolutionary theologian David Friedrich Strauss to the university of Zürich. Bernhard Hirzel voted in his favor.

storyline_title: 1836 in Luzern, the planned dock works w
storyline: Scene:  123#   1836 in Luzern, the planned dock works would not be realized.

storyline_title: 13 February 1837 was a dark day in the l
storyline: Scene:  124#   13 February 1837 was a dark day in the life of Katharina Peyer. It was Carnival in Luzern, but her husband Heinrich Peyer lied already a while ill in bed and died that day from lung haemorrhage, in presence of the helpless Katharina.

storyline_title: A month earlier in the Canton Zürich, Ja
storyline: Scene:  125#   A month earlier in the Canton Zürich, January 18, Pastor Hans Jakob Vogel, pastor of Schwerzenbach, died.

storyline_title: 18 March, Bernhard Hirzel applied for th
storyline: Scene:  126#   18 March, Bernhard Hirzel applied for the vicariate, after the death of H.J. Vogel until the ordination of H. Schweizer. According his own words in his "Rückschau" he considered this a favor ["Gefälligkeit"] and was accepted as vicar in on 4 April 1837.

storyline_title: Heinrich Weiss was still occupied with t
storyline: Scene:  127#   Heinrich Weiss was still occupied with the cantonal transport system and made a complaint on the tracing of the road from Fehraltorf to Rueti through the Ried, on 3 June 1837. Later, on 27 July, he made further petitions concerning this road.

storyline_title: July 29, Bernhard Hirzel left Schwerzenb
storyline: Scene:  128#   July 29, Bernhard Hirzel left Schwerzenbach where soon after, on the 6th of August Heinrich Schweizer would become pastor as Meta Heusser-Schweizer remarked.

storyline_title: In July, Meta Heusser-Schweizer travelle
storyline: Scene:  129#   In July, Meta Heusser-Schweizer travelled to the monastery Pfäffers where she would be soon joined by her children.

storyline_title: In the same moth Emma Herwegh made a tou
storyline: Scene:  130#   In the same moth Emma Herwegh made a tour through Switzerland.

storyline_title: In September, Pfarrer Hans Jakob Meyer,
storyline: Scene:  131#   In September, Pfarrer Hans Jakob Meyer, former pastor of Pfäffikon, was appointed as pastor of the cantonal prison in Oetenbach. On the 12th, Hirzel sended his application for the vacancy in Pfäffikon to Antistes Gessner.

storyline_title: Three days later, the church committee (
storyline: Scene:  132#   Three days later, the church committee (Kirchenstillstand) and the municipal council sended their own nominations to the church council; Kaspar Melchior Wirth a pastor they had already known.

storyline_title: Wirth was not ordinated yet. Therefore w
storyline: Scene:  133#   Wirth was not ordinated yet. Therefore was his election not possible due to the electory conventions of the church and is therefore rejected.

storyline_title: 8 October 1837, Hirzel won the election
storyline: Scene:  134#   8 October 1837, Hirzel won the election as pastor of Pfäffikon. On the 14th, the elections was approved by the State council and on the 24th, the ordination of Pastor Bernhard Hirzel in Pfäffikon took place.

storyline_title: Beginning that month, on the 10th, Katha
storyline: Scene:  135#   Beginning that month, on the 10th, Katharina left the "Engel" and received a "Silver Spoon" from the "Trockenbund".

storyline_title: In 1837, Constantin Siegwart-Müller elec
storyline: Scene:  136#   In 1837, Constantin Siegwart-Müller elected indirectly as Grand Counciler of Luzern and became founder and editor of the "Schweizer Bundeszeitung".

storyline_title: During this time, he worked together wit
storyline: Scene:  137#   During this time, he worked together with his friend Christoph Fuchs, in favor of the radical-liberal chur policy reforms.

storyline_title: 1 Januar 1838, Katharina married the ten
storyline: Scene:  138#   1 Januar 1838, Katharina married the ten years younger Josef Morel in Luzern.

storyline_title: The same day, Bernhard Hirzel moved his
storyline: Scene:  139#   The same day, Bernhard Hirzel moved his furnitures to Pfäffikon.

storyline_title: On February 2nd, Pastor Meyer held a far
storyline: Scene:  140#   On February 2nd, Pastor Meyer held a farewell sermon and in the very night Pfäffikon was set on fire.

storyline_title: Bernhard Hirzel became president of the
storyline: Scene:  141#   Bernhard Hirzel became president of the Fire Controll Commission. Until July he convoked 10 meetings and helps actively in the cleaning up and re-building of the town.

storyline_title: On February 14th, he officially moved to
storyline: Scene:  142#   On February 14th, he officially moved to Pfäffikon and started his work as a pastor on the 25th.

storyline_title: 5 July 1838, the monastery of Pfäffers w
storyline: Scene:  143#   5 July 1838, the monastery of Pfäffers was officially dissoluted. This was a remarkable event for Constantin Siegwart-Müller who later blamed the “tired” Abbot Baumgartner.

storyline_title: The same month, Bernhard Hirzel reported
storyline: Scene:  144#   The same month, Bernhard Hirzel reported to the Church council the truly Christian compassion [ächt christliche Theilname] of the people of Pfäffikon.

storyline_title: 1838 Heinrich Weiss became President of
storyline: Scene:  145#   1838 Heinrich Weiss became President of the War Council and Envoy of the Confederate Diet (Tagsatzungsgesandter). He was also newly elected as member of the State Council.

storyline_title: The Napoleon Affair kept Constantin Sieg
storyline: Scene:  146#   The Napoleon Affair kept Constantin Siegwart-Müller and the whole of Switzerland breathless. He rejected his election to the Small Council.

storyline_title: Somewhen, during those late 30s he final
storyline: Scene:  147#   Somewhen, during those late 30s he finally broke with the radical-liberals and joined the Catholic-conservative reform movement.

storyline_title: 26 January 1839 David Friedrich Strauss
storyline: Scene:  148#   26 January 1839 David Friedrich Strauss was elected for the chair of theology at the University of Zürich. During the parish Chapter, Hirzel relativates the risk of a possible appointment of Strauss.

storyline_title: Two days later, returned Jakob Heusser f
storyline: Scene:  149#   Two days later, returned Jakob Heusser from Zürich and informed his wife Meta Heusser-Schweizer about these news.

storyline_title: Meta Heusser-Schweizer was suddenly affe
storyline: Scene:  150#   Meta Heusser-Schweizer was suddenly affected by an erysipelas (Gesichtsrose).

storyline_title: 13 February 1839 Bernhard Hirzel partici
storyline: Scene:  151#   13 February 1839 Bernhard Hirzel participated in a meeting of deputies from 29 municipalities. They fix 11 points in a missive which goes out to all parishes of the Canton.

storyline_title: On the 17th, the church committee (Kirch
storyline: Scene:  152#   On the 17th, the church committee (Kirchenstillstand), of which Hirzel was member, hold a meeting. Actions in relation to the negative reactions from the people against the appointment of Strauss were discussed.

storyline_title: On the 18th, Hirzel motivated the church
storyline: Scene:  153#   On the 18th, Hirzel motivated the church committee to wait, only an "open revolution" could remove a legally elected person.

storyline_title: Meta Heusser-Schweizer took timely note
storyline: Scene:  154#   Meta Heusser-Schweizer took timely note on these events in her diary.

storyline_title: On the 22nd, the missive arrived in Pfäf
storyline: Scene:  155#   On the 22nd, the missive arrived in Pfäffikon and a Parish Assembly is convoked where they establish a Municipal Committee.

storyline_title: 6 March 1839, the church committee convo
storyline: Scene:  156#   6 March 1839, the church committee convokes a Parish Assembly in reaction to the...

storyline_title: 7 March, The "Wilhelm Tell" started a lo
storyline: Scene:  157#   7 March, The "Wilhelm Tell" started a long line of defamation by different newspapers against Hirzel and the parish assembly.

storyline_title: 8 March, The conservative "Zürcher Freit
storyline: Scene:  158#   8 March, The conservative "Zürcher Freitags-Zeitung" and the radical "Republican" published their opinion on the Assembly of March 6. The "Republican" used the word "terrorism".

storyline_title: 15 March, The "Beobachter" defended Hirz
storyline: Scene:  159#   15 March, The "Beobachter" defended Hirzel's implication as correct, and reject the defamation of the "Republikaner", relativating his role as "leader".

storyline_title: 20 April, Bernhard Hirzel critisized the
storyline: Scene:  160#   20 April, Bernhard Hirzel critisized the religious teaching by Karl Kramers, teacher at the newly founded secondary school [Sekundarschule]. He tries to motivate the Comission of the Secondary School [Sekundarschulkommission] to remove Kramer. He is not succesful until Kramer takes a pro-government position in respect to the Züriputsch.

storyline_title: In July 1839 Georg Herwegh deserted and
storyline: Scene:  161#   In July 1839 Georg Herwegh deserted and fled to Switzerland. Emma Herwegh passed a recreatory stay in Karlsbad.

storyline_title: 27 August, during a meeting of the Paris
storyline: Scene:  162#   27 August, during a meeting of the Parish Chapter (Pastoralgesellschaft Pfäffikon), Hirzel gave a speech "Jetzt ist eine Revolution […] von der Regierung ausgeganten."

storyline_title: In the same month, Heinrich Weiss lost t
storyline: Scene:  163#   In the same month, Heinrich Weiss lost the full support by the citizens of Fehraltorf and moved to Winterthur where he worked as a drapery merchant.

storyline_title: 2 September, 1839 was the Day of Kloten.
storyline: Scene:  164#   2 September, 1839 was the Day of Kloten. Meta Heusser-Schweizer annoted this day in her diary and named the 6th the day of the decision. She stood in Baden in the meanwhile.

storyline_title: 7 September, in the evening, the town of
storyline: Scene:  165#   7 September, in the evening, the town of Pfäffikon was illuminated in honour of Bernhard Hirzel. Antistes Füssli and Bernhard Hirzel became members of the Educational council.

storyline_title: 9 September 1939 Züriputsch.
storyline: Scene:  166#   9 September 1939 Züriputsch.

storyline_title: 23 October 1939, Decan Schweizer describ
storyline: Scene:  167#   23 October 1939, Decan Schweizer described the Faith Committee as a tool of God, during the parish Chapter.

storyline_title: In the same year Bernhard Hirzel’s broth
storyline: Scene:  168#   In the same year Bernhard Hirzel’s brother Johannes divorced from his wife Anna Hirzel-Holzhalb.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart-Müller was member of
storyline: Scene:  169#   Constantin Siegwart-Müller was member of the Grand City Council Luzern and influenced the calling of the Jesuits to the institutions of higher education by Josef Leu who led to a conflict between the conservative cantons.

storyline_title: Siegwart-Müller fought the conservatives
storyline: Scene:  170#   Siegwart-Müller fought the conservatives in his news paper, but already wrote in favor of the "true sovereign of the people (Volksouveränität)" against representational democracy, which would have consequences for Zürich.

storyline_title: The Catholic cantons hold their own conf
storyline: Scene:  171#   The Catholic cantons hold their own conferences on the issues between the State and the Church.

storyline_title: In the meanwhile, Katharina Morel entere
storyline: Scene:  172#   In the meanwhile, Katharina Morel entered the business world and became shareholder of the Stadttheater Luzern, which was still under construction.

storyline_title: 1840 Siegwart-Müller became State Secret
storyline: Scene:  173#   1840 Siegwart-Müller became State Secretary (Staatsschreiber) in Luzern. During the years 1833-1838, the freedom of movement was highly disputed in several cantons and led to the so called Beisassen-Handel in the Canton Schwyz which involved Constantin Siegwart-Müller directly as well as the chief magistrates (Landammänner) Nazar von Reding, Ab Yberg and Fridolin Holdener. This affairs was paralleled by the Horn- und Klauenstreit (horns and claws dispute), in which arguments about rights of cooperative use and the commons (Allmende), extended to general questions in social politics and ended in a mass brawl during the Cantonal Assembly on the 6 May 1838 in Schwyz. Constantin Siegwart-Müller spoke in favor of the Klauen-Party. The Swiss Diet called the troopes and declared the Assembly as invalid. A new Assembly was calle on 22 July 1838 under the observation of the Swiss Diet. As a result the conservative forces, the horn men, would return to power in the forest cantons.

storyline_title: From 1838-1840 Constantin Siegwart-Mülle
storyline: Scene:  174#   From 1838-1840 Constantin Siegwart-Müller remained involved in questions of freedom of movement and further opposes the liberal intents to separate the Church from the State. He took high interest in the appointment of David Friedrich Strauss to the university of Zürich and the later disputes about the universities possible dissolution as proposed by the liberals and supported the conservative side through his news papers.

storyline_title: 27 March 1840, Jules Piaget, whome Emma
storyline: Scene:  175#   27 March 1840, Jules Piaget, whome Emma called her "beloved brother" died.

storyline_title: In July, Meta Heusser-Schweizer made a t
storyline: Scene:  176#   In July, Meta Heusser-Schweizer made a trip to the Rigi.

storyline_title: In 1840, Jakob Robert Steiger, a liberal
storyline: Scene:  177#   In 1840, Jakob Robert Steiger, a liberal and friend, drew a potrait of Constantin Siegwart-Müller.

storyline_title: A constitutional revision hold place in
storyline: Scene:  178#   A constitutional revision hold place in the same year.

storyline_title: 5 November 1840, Siegwart-Müller called
storyline: Scene:  179#   5 November 1840, Siegwart-Müller called the Central Committee of the Ruswiler Club for a meeting. He was secretary and Josef Leu president of the club. On the 25th, he was suspended by the liberal government as state secretary as a threat for the public order.

storyline_title: 30 December 1840, Siegwart-Müller was ce
storyline: Scene:  180#   30 December 1840, Siegwart-Müller was ceased from his position as state secretary by the Grand Council.

storyline_title: 16 February 1841 Bernhard Hirzel was cea
storyline: Scene:  181#   16 February 1841 Bernhard Hirzel was ceased from the Educational council in the same year, Heinrich Weiss became member.

storyline_title: Josef Leu founded his people's party (Vo
storyline: Scene:  182#   Josef Leu founded his people's party (Volkspartei). Siegwart-Müller kept distanciated.

storyline_title: In March, Constantin Siegwart-Müller sen
storyline: Scene:  183#   In March, Constantin Siegwart-Müller sended his "Bemerkungen und Wünsche [Comments and Desires]" from Altorf to Luzern.

storyline_title: The monastry affair (Klosterfrage) in Ca
storyline: Scene:  184#   The monastry affair (Klosterfrage) in Canton Aargau brought the confessional concerns up again in all the Swiss cantons.

storyline_title: 23 May 1841, Regular electios of the Gra
storyline: Scene:  185#   23 May 1841, Regular electios of the Grand Council brought Siegwart-Müller to his position as counciler. He corresponds with Metternich and other foreign governments in hope for support of the conservative cause.

storyline_title: In July, Herwegh's "Gedichte eines Leben
storyline: Scene:  186#   In July, Herwegh's "Gedichte eines Lebendigen" were published.

storyline_title: Meta Heusser-Schweizer passed the month
storyline: Scene:  187#   Meta Heusser-Schweizer passed the month of September on the Rigi.

storyline_title: Emma Siegmund passed her summer holiday
storyline: Scene:  188#   Emma Siegmund passed her summer holiday on the island Helgoland. On her return, in September on the 28rd, she read Georg Herwegh‘s "Gedichte eines Lebendigen".

storyline_title: 22 August 1842, Heinrich Weiss became me
storyline: Scene:  189#   22 August 1842, Heinrich Weiss became member of the District Council for Education in Winterthur.

storyline_title: In September, Georg Herwegh's organized
storyline: Scene:  190#   In September, Georg Herwegh's organized a triumph tour through the German countries.

storyline_title: 6 November 1842, first encounter between
storyline: Scene:  191#   6 November 1842, first encounter between Emma Siegmund and Georg Herwegh. Only 7 days later, on the 13th, Emma Siegmund and Georg Herwegh got engaged at the Siegmund estate.

storyline_title: 19 November, Herwegh had an audience by
storyline: Scene:  192#   19 November, Herwegh had an audience by Friedrich Wilhelm IV.

storyline_title: 28 December 1842, the "Deutsche Bote", a
storyline: Scene:  193#   28 December 1842, the "Deutsche Bote", among other newspapers, was prohibited, letter to the King. Expulsion of Herwegh from the Kingdoms Prussia and Saxon.

storyline_title: Meta Heusser-Schweizer and her family fo
storyline: Scene:  194#   Meta Heusser-Schweizer and her family fought in the meantime against a winter flue. In December, was the confirmation of her son Christian.

storyline_title: The same month, Herwegh traveled onward
storyline: Scene:  195#   The same month, Herwegh traveled onward to Königsberg.

storyline_title: The year 1842, Heinrich Weiss was reelec
storyline: Scene:  196#   The year 1842, Heinrich Weiss was reelected as member of the Grand Council. He became also State council and opposed in this function to the editorial of the Zürcher Blätter.

storyline_title: In Luzern, Siegwart-Müller proposed a mi
storyline: Scene:  197#   In Luzern, Siegwart-Müller proposed a middle way, joining secular priests (clerici saeculari) under the command of a rector. Further, he feigned lack of knowledge about the current situation of the Society of Jesus.

storyline_title: 8 March 1843 Emma Siegmund and Georg Her
storyline: Scene:  198#   8 March 1843 Emma Siegmund and Georg Herwegh married in Baden, Switzerland and enjoyed and extended honeymoon from April to September.

storyline_title: During their voyage they encounter with
storyline: Scene:  199#   During their voyage they encounter with the "Handwerkerkommunisten" Weitling and Becker in Geneva. The travel to Southern France and Italy and enjoy a bathing holiday in Ostende.

storyline_title: 12 July 1843, Meta Heusser-Schweizer’s s
storyline: Scene:  200#   12 July 1843, Meta Heusser-Schweizer’s son Theodor wrote; her comment: “to Berlin”.

storyline_title: 30 August was Missionsfest.
storyline: Scene:  201#   30 August was Missionsfest.

storyline_title: 13 September 1843, Constantin Siegwart-M
storyline: Scene:  202#   13 September 1843, Constantin Siegwart-Müller had become Envoy of the Confederate Diet, and proposed to "refer the conduct of the affair to a permanent conference, along with some instructions on actions military defense becoming the foundation of  the first consultation from which the further developments and finally resulted in the joining of an actual separate alliance arose ".

storyline_title: Until November 1843 three of the dissolv
storyline: Scene:  203#   Until November 1843 three of the dissolved monasteries werepartially restored, among other the monastery Fahr, Einsiedeln, Rheinau (?)

storyline_title: By end of September, in Paris, the coupl
storyline: Scene:  204#   By end of September, in Paris, the couple Herwegh accomodated in an apartement next to Marx and Ruge. Later in November, Georg began his friendship with the Countess Mari d'Agoult (Daniel Stern).

storyline_title: 28 December 1843, Horace Herwegh was bor
storyline: Scene:  205#   28 December 1843, Horace Herwegh was born and the second part of the "Gedichte eines Lebendigen" were published.

storyline_title: 2 February 1844, Bernhard Hirzel was acc
storyline: Scene:  206#   2 February 1844, Bernhard Hirzel was accused in the "Boten von Uster" for the lack of a final balance for the expenses of the Fire Control Committee. Further defamations follow during the following months.

storyline_title: 31 March 1844, the first Volunteerism mo
storyline: Scene:  207#   31 March 1844, the first Volunteerism movement (Freischaarenzug) took actions.

storyline_title: During the same month in Paris, Emma dis
storyline: Scene:  208#   During the same month in Paris, Emma discovered Georg Herwegh's affair with Marie d'Agoult, writes in her diary.

storyline_title: In Silesia, the Weberaufstand [weaver up
storyline: Scene:  209#   In Silesia, the Weberaufstand [weaver uprising] took place from the 4th to the 6th of June, and even though, it was not the largest or most intensive one of a series of weaver uprisings in Germany, it achieve unknown coverage by the media.

storyline_title: For Emma Herwegh this was rather an oppo
storyline: Scene:  210#   For Emma Herwegh this was rather an opportunity to take up the fight with her rival, competing in the aesthetic literary salons and beginning her political activity, starting from July.

storyline_title: 19 June 1844, Josef Morel, after much wo
storyline: Scene:  211#   19 June 1844, Josef Morel, after much worries due to family issues, and herritage disputes, died unexpectedly. Katharina had to restructure her financial budget.

storyline_title: The day after, Meta Heusser-Schweizer re
storyline: Scene:  212#   The day after, Meta Heusser-Schweizer recorded in her diary Zar Alexander I.’s visit of the Bible Society in London.

storyline_title: 4 December 1844, Johann Jakob Blumer an
storyline: Scene:  213#   4 December 1844, Johann Jakob Blumer an Alfred Escher, Glarus, Mittwoch, 4. Dezember 1844: wrote against any liberal intents of a Putsch and believed that waiting a while more, the people would get tired of Siegwart and change their direction.

storyline_title: But liberal governments thought otherwis
storyline: Scene:  214#   But liberal governments thought otherwise and the volunteers engaged in agitations which were defeated in Luzern only four days later on the 8th of December. Equally, Constantin Siegwart-Müller, who was chief magistrate (Schultheiss) by this time and led the coup, as well as Katharina Morel, who belonged to the Pepper women (Pfefferfrauen), a female radical-liberal guerilla who supported the volunteerism movement during 1844-1845, annotated this date.

storyline_title: Besides all the turmoils, in 1844 finall
storyline: Scene:  215#   Besides all the turmoils, in 1844 finally the docks were built in Luzern, and the hotel "Schweizerhof" was built in 1844/45 by the brothers Xaver and Josef Plazidus Segesser as  a building with 15 axes.

storyline_title: Constantin Siegwart-Müller was appointed
storyline: Scene:  216#   Constantin Siegwart-Müller was appointed President of the Confederate Diet and supported secretly Leu in his plan to install the Jesuit Order.

storyline_title: 16 January 1845, Heinrich Weiss reported
storyline: Scene:  217#   16 January 1845, Heinrich Weiss reported on an assembly in the Canton Zürich:

storyline_title: Es war winterlich kalt an diesem 26. Jan
storyline: \N

storyline_title: FADE IN:
storyline: FADE IN: In the Valley of Saga. A group of people is sitting around a table on a beautivul terrasse, next to a small river. They drink milk coffee and eat a delicious Napoleon Pastry.

storyline_title: FADE IN:
storyline: A messenger approaches them and gives them a note. It says that the president of Germany was in serious dispair. She had to lead Europe in a time when it was torn apart by internal antisystem movements and threatened by the growing Islamic State. Therefore, she asked the anscestors to give her an advice.

storyline_title: FADE IN:
storyline: Some of them are a little bit set up that she had woken up the death. Still they try to help her and discuss on how they had handle such issues in the past.

storyline_title: Scene 1: luzern
storyline: The first time I had seen him was when my mother died. By this time, I didn't know what it was, but I learnt soon what it meant.

storyline_title: Scene 2: luzern
storyline: I lost everything, my home in Luzern, where I was born. My father sold the Inn we run, and I had to live with my aunt in Kriens.

storyline_title: Scene 3: luzern
storyline: We had been obliged to host French soldiers already the years before, and the imposition of the Continental system made things not better. Businesses in Luzern were small and without perspective. But I never let anybody control me and rejected all pretendents.

storyline_title: Scene 4: Luzern
storyline: Until I met him. He was so funny, the Peyer. We should become true compagnion in arms.

storyline_title: Scene 5: Beresina
storyline: He was a saddler and had tried his luck. But people payed late or never. Peyer was also often ill. When he had to hire new soldiers for Napoleon, I had to do the job for him many times. But finally, he decided to list voluntarily for military service to the great Napoleon. This filled him with hope for a change, a more stable economy. How wrong we were...

storyline_title: scene 6: Beresina
storyline: Death was not my only enemy. Yes, I was sad, destroyed when my dear parents died. But it was also the beginning of a new life for me.

storyline_title: scene 7: Ticino
storyline: What could a glassworker's son strive for by this time? My foster father was a great man, a Catholic priest. He educated me in the Scholastic and send me to even to the best, liberal universities.
notes: Chronology sequence 7 and 19; Morel, 1873, p. xy

storyline_title: scene 8: Uri
storyline: I achieved citizenship in Uri, had written the "Tell" in order to promote me. Further, I was public prosecutor.

storyline_title: scene 9: Uri
storyline: Finally, I married one of the most noble women in Uri. I had calculated well my social ascend. And I had great luck. Josefine became not only my wife, but also my confident, my friend.

storyline_title: scene 10: fehraltorf
storyline: Constantin, you are right. A good education was key for our social ascend. It was a luck, that already my father was a teacher and he spent his last money to send me to the public high school in Aarau. A foreing university was beyond our possibilities.
notes: Chronology sequence 10 and 48; Morel, 1873, p. xy

storyline_title: scene 11: Kyburg
storyline: I would become tribunal and even Police Council, Grand Councilor and member of the State Council, later in the 30s.

storyline_title: scene 12: Fehraltorf
storyline: But I was not so lucky in love as you two. My first wife died early after our marriage.

storyline_title: scene 13: fehraltorf
storyline: One thing was clear for me, if our society should be more just we needed the possibility to study for everybody, better public schools and credit for the small people.

storyline_title: scene 14: zürich
storyline: Do you really believe that things were only difficult for the land people? We aristocrats desired a change more than anybody else. My father was a violent alcoholic without perspectives. He could only think about making money.
notes: Chronology sequences 17 and 43; Morel, 1873, p. xy

storyline_title: scene 15: zürich
storyline: But money was not all in life. I realized this when I started my Sanskrit studies. This was a full new world; a free world.

storyline_title: scene 16: zürich
storyline: Love, yes, love was what I longed for. But I never found it really. My emotions were my true opponent in life.

storyline_title: scene 17: hirzel
storyline: The Mediation and the Restauration were very agitated times. I remember them well. The Bocken inn war, the fire of the nearby villages when the French had passed through.

storyline_title: scene 18: hirzel
storyline: You know, Bernhard, you are not completly wrong. Love is important.

storyline_title: scene 18: hirzel
storyline: But you confused physical love with true love. Even the love of your enemy.

storyline_title: scene 19: hirzel
storyline: I found my love, the Heusser, but it was not always easy with him.

storyline_title: scene 20: hirzel
storyline: You two dreamed with the liberals, they should bring more freedom. But religious freedom was not guaranteed. Remeber, how the Anabaptist were still persecuted; almost as in times of Zwingli and Bullinger.

storyline_title: scene 21: Luzern
storyline: This is why I returned to my Catholic faith.

storyline_title: scene 22: luzern
storyline: Leu had understood this long before me. At the beginning I was skeptic.

storyline_title: scene 23: Luzern
storyline: Comme on, you were an opportunist! Did you not achieve the citizenship in Luzern only because you were friend of the liberals, especially Casimir Pfyffer?

storyline_title: scene 24: GORUM
storyline: I had lost so many things. I really learnt what war meant. Several times I lost my houshold goods, and several times almost my life. At the end, Death took my Peyer. On Carnival,isn't that grotesk!

storyline_title: scene 25: LUZERN --
storyline: But we liberals had improved life so much. Finally, the steam boat docked in Luzern. The public schools were increased and the educational law enforced.

storyline_title: scenen 26: HIRZEL
storyline: Life had taken much from me, but it had also given. I had never had children, but the death of my dear sister-in-law gave me also a daughter, my dear Katharina.

storyline_title: scene 27: LUZERN --
storyline: Even my second husband died - he was ten years younger, who would ever have thought that he died earlier than me? But he taught me much about business. I became even a shareholder of the new theatre in Luzern and finally the manager of the Schweizerhof!

storyline_title: scene 28: HIRZEL --
storyline: It is true, life had given us much to all of us, I think especially of my children.

storyline_title: scenen 29: RIGI
storyline: I had seen the progress in Luzern when I returned to it on my trip to the Rigi.

storyline_title: scene 30: RIGI
storyline: I had travelled a lot during the late 20s and early 30s and saw how the country changed. We all wished a school reform, but you the liberals abused of it and tried to impose your philosophy on everybody. And how you used the press to influence the people, to boost things, not to speak of the Volunteer movement!

storyline_title: scene 31:HIRZEL
storyline: But also you, the conservatives pured much oil into the fire with your "Bundeszeitung".

storyline_title: scene 32: HIRZEL
storyline: And then you thought you had to fight for your faith with weapons! My poor Heusser, how confused he was. All this affected me so much that I suffered from a terrible erysipelas for the third time.

storyline_title: scene 33: HIRZEL
storyline: However, the true history was a hidden one. My dear mother had taught me that.

storyline_title: scene 34: HIRZEL
storyline: The real change had to occure in our hearts, and I was so happy, that Zar Alexander supported our missionary efforts.

storyline_title: scene 35: PARIS
storyline: What are you speaking about? Constantin: Meta was suggesting that the true story was a hidden one. Emma: You are right. I also had faught on the battle field; for the children of Liberty, for me. But the change came from within our minds, all these discussions in my saloon, this is were the new world was cemented.

storyline_title: scene 36: BERLIN
storyline: My salvator was Georg, his poem of a "living man", it gave me true life. I had been so bored and finally found purpose in his, our fight.

storyline_title: scene 37: ZÜRICH
storyline: This is why writing was important, it could change minds. But at the end, it could also be dangerous. We had to leave Zürich for it, and all my life I had to live in economic misery. The time was not ready yet, by then.

storyline_title: scene 38: ZÜRICH
storyline: You are brave Emma. This was my cardinal sin. I had not faith and believed that I had to take care for economic issues.

storyline_title: scene 39: ZÜRICH
storyline: This is were my disaster began, because I had fooled my true love; Sanskrit studies.
notes: Chronology scene 180, 205, suicide?; Morel, 1873, p. xy

storyline_title: scene 40: ZÜRICH
storyline: The press accused me much after the Züriputsch, they blamed me for being violent and a Don Juan. But I took care for everybody and had been able to pay all my debth back.

storyline_title: scene 40: ZÜRICH
storyline: If there had not been so much conspiration against me, even from my own family.

storyline_title: scene 41: ZÜRICH
storyline: All I had done was for love. I took the position as a parson in order to care for my young family, and I helped the village people after the fire. They loved so much for my support during the Züriputsch. Their faith was honest, and the liberals only speculated to destroy the church from within.

storyline_title: scene 42: ZÜRICH
storyline: Sorry, I could not avoid listening to your conversation. Love, liberty, ... Can you hear yourself? It almost sounds as if we, the liberals had been rouug conquerors of poor village people. Our true "guilt" had been to be too timid, hesitating all the time, going for and backwards. The conservatives were no innocent victims. Or had you seriously wished the Jesuits returned to the schools; mistaking teaching with blind recitation of the Bible?

storyline_title: scene 43: WINTERTHUR
storyline: Hi, Alfred! Nice to meet you again. You are so right. It had to be said that we too defended our faith. Those who opposed the Jesuits were also the "people". Hesitating could be as dammaging as a too quick and thoughless action.

storyline_title: scene 44: LUZERN
storyline: Please, comme on! From your mouth it sounds as if the Sonderbund was a football game. People had died! I had lost all my goods and I had to live ten years in exile, with all my family. This was no children's game!

storyline_title: scene 45: ZÜRICH
storyline: Alfred, I know you, we sat often together. Don't tell me now that you worried for the "faith" of the liberals. You only longed for money and power.

storyline_title: scene 46: TEXAS
storyline: Karl, who had keep silence so far so how Alfred got more and more stressed. He layed his hand on Alfred's shoulder and said: Why are you fighting? What are you fighting for? Liberty, the people? Everybody was fighting for this in Europe. And this was nothing! I was in Texas, there they even treated some people worse than animals. Our, the Swiss merit was that we had found a way to live with our opponents, besides unsolved conflicts.

storyline_title: scene 47: TEXAS
storyline: I had wished a socialist state; the Phalange. That's why I joined in to the idea of direct democracy.

storyline_title: scene 48: GERMANY
storyline: You are right, Karl. I had always tried to find a compromise. This is probabely the reason why the let me return to Switzerland towards the end, and why I was able to forgive.

storyline_title: scene 49: GERMANY
storyline: But the past had learnet me something, that at times one was forced to take a decision. Failing to do so, would also lead to a decision, but it would stay out of your control. My wrong decisions had only brought me closer to my God. He would bring the reign of God one day.

storyline_title: scene 50: HIRZEL
storyline: The reign of God was not of this world.

storyline_title: scene 51: PARIS
storyline: This is exactly what I thought. It's all illusion, all Maya. At the end, why fighting any longer. I just couldn't anymore. There was nothing that expected me in life. This is why united with my grand love Marie, my Virign, we took our lives.

storyline_title: scene 52: LUZERN
storyline: Don't say this. I have fought so much. But all achieving is nothing, because at the end you will not take it with anyway. I learnt that I had to leave something behind. Haven't cared, Bernhard, for finishing your Sanskrit books before leaving this world? Don't be a hypocrite!

storyline_title: scene 53: GENEVA
storyline: This is why we from the First International and the Women's Movement did not go the way of violence. And no-one could ever say, that I feared a good fight. But that would not lead to the liberty we desired.

storyline_title: scene 54: ZÜRICH
storyline: You sound like those crazy "Schwärmer". If you go on like this you will end as Bernhard did - believing all is an illusion. There are decision which had to be taken.

storyline_title: scene 55: ZÜRICH
storyline: And we took them. Yes, we did, but each of us according his or her own consciousness.

storyline_title: scene 56: ZÜRICH
storyline: But there must be one truly right decision.

storyline_title: scene 57: ZÜRICH
storyline: Yes, there was one. The one that included us all.
